It has a +20 knowledge bonus concerning monsters of a specific type (plants, fiends etc.). Gain bane against this creature type.Unique Property - Each legendary weapon is unique and has something that aids and defeating its favored foe. Some examples below.

item.title: master
item.description: Through dumb luck, large quantities of practical experience or intensive research, you have reached a level of mastery demanding of respect from all mortals, and perhaps even those greater than mortal.Gain the following benefits… TECHNIQUE - Create your own school of techniques and make 6 techniques, one for each level. You automatically have all of them memorized without spending memory.Mana Cheating - You restore mana at the start of each turn regardless of if you spend it or notSignature Technique - You can innately cast a level 3 or lower technique you could normally cast. Its DC increases by 2.If you aren't up to the task of making a bunch of content, instead gain this boon TECHNIQUE - Immediately gain 3 technique points and 3 memory slots.

item.title: README
item.description: Most classes stop gaining features at level 11, but every class universally has access to ascendance, which is granted at level 12. After which the content train stops. Ascendances are meant to cater to a fantasy where after a character's journey has gone on long enough, they not only acquire power, but also often prestige. Ascendances can often be summed up in a single title like "immortal" or "archmage" or "demigod."

item.title: achievements
item.description: Achievements are archetypal tasks that provide some kind of tangible benefit after completion. You do not need to opt into an achievement, instead they can be claimed retroactively after accomplishing a task.Battle ScarsRequirement - Get defeated by a critical hit and survive in 3 different encounters. Or get crit 3 times in the same combat and survive.Reward - The scars you get from battle are deeply entrenched in your memory. Your memories of combats you have encountered cannot be magically removed. By touching them, you can perfectly recall past events, as long as they happened in the thick of combat. Other creatures can touch your scars to share in the experience of the memoryBackstabberRequirement - Murder 3 people you once considered allies, or who at thought you were an ally (before you turned on them). If you murder someone in a position of great power, like a powerful guild leader or king, it counts as 3.Reward - You have a 6th sense for when people trust you. By observing how they react to your presence in a brief interaction (such as an introduction), you can tell whether they trust you, are indifferent towards you or if they distrust you.Critical PetRequirement - Use stealth to initiate combat on a creature by patting its head 3 times. This pat can have no mechanical effect such as delivering a spell or attacking.Reward - You unlock the "Pet" skill, usable for memes. It uses your stealth bonus. If you sneak up on a creature and pet their head (again, no additional mechanical effect), you establish dominance, giving you a +2 bonus to skills for the subsequent social or combat encounter. If a creature within reach is smaller than you, you can pet them as a free action 1/turn for no mechanical benefit (no save).

item.title: progression-outside-of-class
item.description: Just so its all in one place.Boons/Banes - Gained at level one as a result of having positive or negative luck.Feats - Gained at level 1, and every odd level after.Technique Points - Gain one that can be used on any school of techniques at level 2, and every even level after.Ascendance - Unique template applied at level 12.Achievements - Can be gained at any time, even retroactively, when certain conditions are met, varying based on the achievement

item.title: class-descriptions-completion-status
item.description: This section primarily exists to give you a starting point to see what you're interested in.Because this is early access, not all the classes are done (C) denotes that the class is complete, often with a variety of options (P) denotes the class is playable, but lacking in variety or later levels are sparse (ND) denotes the class is still in not done, and is largely unplayable

item.title: distributing-ability-scores
item.description: Read the core mechanics section in order to get a better understanding of the function of each ability score. Every character gets starting 6 points to invest in their ability scores as they wish/ Every point you increase in ability score counts against this total. You can decrease an ability score to -1 in order to gain an additional point. The maximum points you can invest is 3. The minimum is -1.

item.title: main-character-status
item.description: Have you ever wanted to write an epic story for a character you made? How they survived a bloody conflict, went through incredibly rigorous training to become the best and brightest mage, was chosen by god or some other equally astonishing development. Then the game says "you die in one hit to a goblin."While not entirely unrealistic, it doesn't make for very satisfying gameplay to have your character feel like they are made out of paper and are one stray crit away from instant death. A game like DnD 5e remedies this by making KO'd a state your character falls in and out of multiple times as a result of "le nat 20," spammable low action healing and a lack of negative hit points.If you want the player characters to be invincible compared to monsters of a similar level, I say skip the pretense. Player characters are of a different breed and are hardened by their previous adventures, granting the following benefits…HP - Your hp is increased by 10. Defeat - You do not have a chance to instantly die when you fall unconscious, instead you receive a stacking debuff called doom. You also accumulate afflictions.With this change, a measure of how worn down you are can be more easily tied to how much hp you have. There are obviously other factors, but you can't ever keep adventuring without hp. Mana is the general resource system tied to using special abilities, and it naturally recharges when not used.In general healing that keeps you at full HP all the time is intended to be more scarce, and usually come at the cost of reducing your max mana until you rest.In general, only PCs will have this buff. But BBEGs, legendary creatures and other major bosses intended for use at the end of major story beats could also receive a similar version of this buff. Then you can get the juicy "phase transition" threshold to give your big boss encounters more punch.

item.title: README
README
Tactician
item.description:
Fighter Archetype.
CrusttttYtttt.y11

item.title: Bleeding
item.description:
Bleeding creatures take a specified amount of Damage at the start of each of their turns for a specified duration. If no duration is specified, it lasts indefinitely. The DC to stop the bleeding (with the Medicine skill, or magic healing with a CL check) is the attacker's Lv+12.
Instead of taking damage, bleed prevents a creature from losing the Defeated condition when healed (unless the healing removes the bleed).
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Bleeding.md

item.title: Focus
item.description:
Choose a creature you can see. For 1 round you gain the following benefits... Your movement is elusive to them You can take an immediate action as an instant action 1/turn in response to their actions. You cannot be denied instant actions and immediate actions against the focused creature, even while DD.
While you focus on a creature, you pay less attention to all other creatures, and are automatically DD to them. You can choose to continue or end focus on a creature on subsequent turns as a free action.Special - In organized duels, it is assumed both characters start the combat in this state. In such circumstances, they ignore the DD portion of this action (for companions and such).
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Common Actions/Standard Actions/Focus.md

item.title: Crit
item.description: Critical hits occur when you roll 10 higher than a creature's AC. Crits deal 1.5x damage.Its also worth noting here that all damage multipliers are additive.For example, group type enemies like swarms takes 1.5x damage from AoE. If you Cleave and crit, you deal 2x damage.

item.title: Divine Shield
item.description: A shimmering barrier forms around a creature. They are immune to Poise damage and cannot be Grazed while it persists. The next instance of hitpoint damage they suffer is negated in its entirety, also preventing any additional effects that damage would inflict (such as On-hit effects).
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Divine Shield.md

item.title: True Damage
item.description: True damage cannot be reduced by anything. Resistance, DR you name it. The most common source of true damage is Bleeding
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/True Damage.md

item.title: On-hit
item.description: On-hit effects only happen when you successfully match or exceed a creature's AC and deal damage to a creature (AKA it is not negated by DR/Resistance). The effect does not occur on a graze.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/On-hit.md

item.title: Recharge
item.description: Recharge abilities have a specific criteria or time required until they can be used again.If no such criteria or duration is listed, then it is assumed that the recharge is resting, making it a 1/day ability.

item.title: Sp
item.description: Spell abilities encompass any ability that is magical that is a Spell.Sometimes used in notation for abilities that mimic or function like spells.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/Sp.md

item.title: Iron Knuckle
item.description:
Fighter Archetype.Your armor is a second skin to you. Your armor is also your first skin. The iron knuckle has 2 "phases" to their battles. The first is a walking tank with multiple layers of armor, durable and stubborn until you get to the squishy single layer of plate armor underneath. The second is a nimble warrior that gets a boost of adrenaline, feeling light as a feather just after their outer shell is cracked open.Iron knuckles are practically invincible to being attacked head on while layered up, and must be ganged up. Mages will find a much easier time breaking the outer layer.
Iron Knuckle, as it appears in the LoZ seriesYou are fused with a set of standard metal plate armor. You can enhance this armor with new metals and enchantments with a more involved process. You are permanently treated as though you are wearing heavy armor. It is part of you and cannot be separated without causing permanent life-threatening damage to you.Because this armor is a part of you, it being destroyed hurts you. Whenever your armor is destroyed/degraded you take 10 damage.You add construct to your creature types. You gain proficiency in the profession (blacksmith) skill.You can choose to put on an additional layer of heavy armor over the first, providing you with the following benefits after 1 minute of preparation. +4 AC
You benefit from the Quake technique constantly While layered up you also take a -10 penalty to your speed and cannot fly or hover. Enemies can remove layer up by dealing damage that drops you below half hp. It takes 3 rounds to remove layer up manually.It requires a set of heavy armor in order to use layer up. When an enemy removes layer up, you cannot use that particular set of heavy armor to layer up again until you repair it. Be sure to pick it up after the battle!After carrying the weight of incredibly heavy metal armor during the heat of battle, to have the burden removed suddenly fills the iron knuckle with new vigor. When an enemy removes layer up from you, you become light as a feather, gaining the following benefits.
You gain (10+2xLv) temp hp (healing), potentially preventing you from dying from single instances of damage. Your speed and jump distance increases by 10 until combat ends.
You can choose to be immediately effected by the Unbreakable Advance technique. You gain access to the sudden strike special attack until combat ends.
Special Attack: Sudden Strike - Advance 10 ft towards an enemy elusive and make a melee attack. On hit the target is pushed back 5 feet and knocked down. On a graze the target is only pushed back 5 ft. Deals an additional d6/odd lvl damage.
You gain the power pose feat. When you use it, it deals 15 poise damage instead of 10.If you are layered up then you can use it as an instant action 1/turn. You can use power pose against AoOs an unlimited number of times as an instant action.You can choose if you want to leave a creature at 1 poise, or poise break them with this ability. If a creature is poise broken by this ability then they are made clumsy 2, or you can sunder the equipment used to attack.While light as a feather, when a creature misses you with an AoO, or you successfully use acrobatics to evade AoOs, you can make a bully attack as an instant action.If you are layered up, when you shove a creature, you can move with them to increase the shove distance by your remaining movement.
While light as a feather, you gain powerful charge.If you are layered up then you are immune to fatigue.
You gain the innate technique adrenaline burst while light as a feather.
You are immune to attack rolls made by minions while layered up. Any minion that attacks you is instead set to 1 poise automatically as it bounces off of your metal body.
While light as a feather, you gain resistance to damage from failed saving throws.Strike at a foe, dealing an additional 6d6 (21) damage. If you are layered up, gain temp hp and poise equal to the total damage dealt. If light as a feather, also immediately layer up again until this temp hp is lost.This poise recovery cannot exceed your poise maximum.

item.title: Index
item.description: Nick Nacks is my very own fantasy tabletop role-playing game (TTRPG). My biggest sources of inspiration are Pathfinder 1e and Divinity Original Sin 2.Most of the rules in Nick Nacks are centered around combat. I expect you to be traveling through dangerous wilderness, delving into dungeons and stealing treasure from dragons. Some rules, such as skills and mini games, allow you to resolve actions outside of combat, like chases and drinking contests.Where I think Nick Nacks shines is its customization options for players and DMs alike. Instead of having traditional spell lists, I made techniques for both martials and mages, each with their own group loosely centered around a theme such as pyromancy, unarmed fighting or necromancy.I have plans to make far, far more classes, subclasses, bestiary creatures, feats and more!

item.title: Bloody Finger
Basic Bitch Fighter
item.description: Fighter Archetype.For when you really don't want to think about complicated class features.You gain a bonus feat every level. Every time you gain a technique point, you can choose to instead turn it into a feat.You get access to the following feats, each of which can be taken any number of times.Ability Increase - Increase an ability score by +1 (up to +3)Super Strength - Increase strength by +1 (up to +5).Super Armor - Gain +1 AC (up to +3).Power Stance - Gain +3 poise.Paladin Cosplay - Get a +1 bonus to saving throws (up to +3).Superior Genetics - Get an additional major feature from your race

item.title: deadly arsenal
Magical Beasts
item.description:
Classes/Beast Trainer/Beast Trainer Archetype.Magical Beasts use their casting to enhance their beast companions. They are able to combo their spells with their beast.This archetype replaces Tandem Strike.
Your beast companion benefits from any technique you have prepared with the prepared tag.
Whenever you use a technique with the Buff tag, you can also affect your beast companion with it.The DC for your spells is 2 higher against any creature your beast companion has attacked this turn. You get advantage on attacks with spells against any creature your beast companion has attacked this turn.
You automatically exclude your beast companion from any damage or CC that your techniques inflict.Choose a magical technique tree. You gain a technique point in this tree at level 1 and every two levels after.
Whenever a creature fails a save against one of your techniques, it Provokes from your beast companion.

item.title: Prey Seeker
item.description:
Classes/Beast Trainer/Beast Trainer Archetype.Prey seekers use beast companions to harass their opponents, keeping them at a distance so you can hit them from afar. Your companion can rush back to your aid when needed.
Your movement is Elusive against creatures your beast companion threaten.Your beast companion gains the following special attack. Special Attack: To My Side - The beast companion can move 30 ft closer to you and attack a creature threatening you. If its current speed is less than 30 ft, this special attack's additional movement decreases to that reduced speed.
You gain a technique point in the Marksmanship tree at this level and every two levels after.
Attach a tasty treat to your next ranged attack. On hit, apply a treat. Your beast companion gains seeking against the creature for 1 minute. Your beast companion heals (3+Lv) on hit on their first attack against this creature.
Your beast companion gets the sentinel feat.
You get a +2 bonus to ACC against creatures your beast companion threatens, as though you were flanking. Your beast companion gets the following special attack. Special Attack: Bother - Your companion taunts a creature on hit.

item.title: +Achievement
item.description: Achievements are archetypal tasks that provide some kind of tangible benefit after completion. You do not need to opt into an achievement, instead they can be claimed retroactively after accomplishing a task.

item.title: ankylotortoise
Ability Scores
item.description:
These are representations of a creature's innate or cultivated affinities. These represent the mind, body, and spirit. The ability scores are Strength, Dexterity, Luck, Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma.
Every Player Character gets 6 points to increase their ability scores as they wish, starting from 0 in each.You can decrease a ability scores to -1 in order to gain an additional point. The maximum points you can invest in a given ability score is 3.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Ability Scores/Ability Scores.md

item.title: Ability Scores
Prepared
item.description: This technique does not require any form of activation to use. It provides its benefit constantly.

item.title: Attack
item.description:
Attack rolls are any type of harmful effect targeting a creature that does not require a saving throw. This can be spells, swords or trying to push your foe off a cliff.Most attacks assume you use a weapon, a Natural Weapon or an unarmed strike.Default:d20+ (lvl) +(ability score) +/- (circumstances)
In general AC is not a zero sum endeavor. If you successfully meet the AC number, you deal full damage. if you roll 10 higher than the AC number, you Crit. If you roll under the AC number, but not by more than 5, you get a partial hit as you graze your opponent with your attack.
Generally speaking, you can only make a single attack with your standard action, but creatures with multiattack, and special cases like Classes/Fighter/Fighter or Martial Artist, can make multiple on their turn.

item.title: Dazed
item.description:
A more severe version of Staggered. Creature cannot take a Standard Action and cannot make
AoOs.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Dazed.md

item.title: Confused
item.description: You consider all creatures enemies. Every turn, roll a d10 to determine how you act. Many effects allow you to increase the dice roll with a will save. For confusion effects that last more than 1 round, each subsequent d10 roll gets 2 added to the result.The confusion result is the only thing the creature does on their turn, ie if you roll a 5 you wander and then end turn.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Confused.md

item.title: Frosty
item.description: Creature is covered in ice. Creature has Resistance to Fire Damage and -15 Speed. Attacks against a frosty creature get +2 ACC. This status ends when they take physical or fire damage.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Frosty.md

item.title: Status
item.description:
A Status Effect is a condition that is placed on a creature to apply CC, change their rolls, and otherwise modify how they interact with the world... For better or for worse.See:
Ablaze
Affliction
Anchored
Asleep
Bleeding
Blinded
Blurred Vision
Charmed
Frosty
Clumsy
Confused
Cursed
Dazed
Defeated
Dominated
Drained
Entangled
Entombed
Fascinated
Fatigued
Frightened
Glowing
Grounded
Held Down
Invincible
Invisible
Knocked Down
Mindless
Necrosed
Pacified
Prone
Shaken
Sickened
Silenced
Siphoned
Staggered
Stasis
Stunned
Submerged
DD
Taunted
Time Out
Unassailable
Unstoppable
Untargetable
Wet
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Status.md

item.title: Charmed
item.description: Creature cannot attack the entity that inflicted this condition. The entity that inflicted this condition has a +4 bonus on Charisma Skills against this creature.This ends if the creature that inflicted the condition harms the charmed creature.Charmed creatures always interpret what the creature that charmed them is doing in the most positive light: Punches and sword swings are massages and surgeries. Charmed creatures are often willing to do things asked of them provided they don't put the creature in danger or clash with their ethos. After the charm ends, acts are seen for what they truly are.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Charmed.md

item.title: Asleep
item.description: Asleep: This creature is Knocked Down, can take no actions, and cannot be awakened unless it takes damage, is subject to an offensive ability or an ally uses the Aid action to awaken them. The creature is also DD and suffers -10 Perception.If the creature is asleep through natural means, it can use perception to wake up by noticing something amiss.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Asleep.md

item.title: Anchored
item.description: Creature cannot use Teleportation effects. Either on themselves or on others. If they attempt to do so, the effect fizzles.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Anchored.md

item.title: Ablaze
item.description: When a creature is set Ablaze, it takes 2d8 Fire Damage at the start of each turn. Attacking creatures get a +2 bonus to ACC. On every turn after the first, it gets a Reflex save before it takes damage to end the effect. A creature can choose to inflict Knockdown on itself at the end of its turn for a +4 bonus to this save.Being submerged in water, getting entombed or taking cold damage also removes this condition. Other things that snuff out flames can reasonably remove ablaze.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Ablaze.md

item.title: Stacking Damage and Defense
item.description: When you stack a source of flat damage reduction and multiplicative reduction, add them together in the way that reduces the damage the most.When you have multiple sources of increasing damage by a percentage, add the percentages together, do not multiply (ie 1.5x dmg and 1.5x dmg adds together to 2x dmg).
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/More Rules/Stacking Damage and Defense.md

item.title: +Death and Resurrection
item.description:
Let's be honest, the purpose of resurrection in TTRPGs is primarily for the benefit of the players. If a DM makes frequent use of the resurrection spells for entities that the players went to great lengths to kill, it heavily undermines their effort and feels terrible, even if plausible. If all it takes is a bunch of money and a cleric, then rich high level players live in a world without death as a consequence for anybody.Now that we all agree about that, why does resurrection have an expensive material component cost? To punish the players for being unlucky? Why is it locked behind high-level magic? To make playing cleric mandatory? If we only consider the players, then these things become very obvious problems. Players shouldn't be shoehorned into playing specific classes, nor should the money that they worked hard to obtain be required to continue playing the game.The powers that be should instead be very particular about the who gets a second chance. If the players are the main character of the story, then the game's resurrection mechanics should treat them as such. As a replacement for most resurrection effects, use these rules instead. Or don't use resurrection at all. It's your game. Whatever.IMPORTANT NOTE: Please make sure your players are on board with whatever you decide. Nobody likes surprise mechanics.Isn't this just plot armor? The basic premise of this system of resurrection is that you want player death to have immediate consequences: Not being able to complete a mission or delaying the players long enough so that way the villain can complete the ritual. But you don't want them to have long-term consequences: Not being able to play your character. Having to go on lengthy multi-session quests to find someone willing and able to cast the correct spell to bring you back can be fun, but after a few times, it can get old.So in order to achieve the former and avoid the latter, it's recommended that you bake the reason for the players coming back from the dead into the story. Death still matters or course, after all the players will have allies (:<If your players aren't too attached to their characters, then who needs plot armor? Let 'em die. If they are, consider some of the options in this section.See: Ashen One
Cloning Device
Limited Resurrection
Tombstone
Withers
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Death and Resurrection/+Death and Resurrection.md

item.title: Fall Damage
item.description:
Fall damage increases by 3 Crush for every 10 feet you fall, capped at 60 damage. Every 50 feet you are also Drained 1, capped at 4. You take Poise damage equal to the crush damage you took. If this breaks your poise, you are Knocked Down.
When determining fall distance, subtract your Jump.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/More Rules/Fall Damage.md

item.title: Rest
item.description:
8 consecutive hours of sleep. If you sleep in undesirable conditions, you can still rest, but you are exhausted the following day.Some conditions, such as a bumpy ride, a bed of rocks or an incredibly loud house can prevent you from resting at all.
When you rest, you restore your HP and mana burn. You also can use abilities with limited uses per day.

item.title: Natural Healing
item.description: In the absence of danger, a defeated creature will regain 1 hp after 1 hour. They are staggered until they are healed or they rest.With a proper 8 hours rest, a character restores all their HP, all of their daily use abilities and recover mana burn. You can only rest once each day.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Hitpoints/Natural Healing.md

item.title: +HP
item.description: How much hp a player has is largely determined by their class. Creatures have a base hp value of 20, and then a value that they add each Lv, including level one. Classes and creatures all fall under one of the following categories based on their play style.

item.title: Ranged Attack
item.description:
A Ranged Attack is an Attack made with ranged targeting. This means you can make the attack up to the listed range, not limited by the space you Threaten. These attacks can also be penalized due to Cover. Physical Ranged Attacks have three listed ranges: thrown, short and long.
Making a Ranged Attack Provokes.
Abilities that function from a distance but do not use an Attack Roll are not Ranged Attacks.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Attacking/Ranged Attack.md

item.title: Special Attack
item.description:
Special attacks allow for more versatility in play style. Weapons, class abilities, techniques and
Feats can grant these special attacks. Special attacks can usually only be performed once per turn.
Special attacks universally have the martial tag.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Attacking/Special Attack.md

item.title: Attack Progression
item.description: Creatures that aren't dual-wielding have only 1 attack by default. When you use your standard action to make multiple attacks, it's called a multiattack. You can distribute the attacks to creatures as you see fit, move in between them, before and after them (for certain AoE attacks like cleave, you usually need to stand still). By default a standard attack is considered a simple attack.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Attacking/Attack Progression.md

item.title: Weapon
item.description:
Weapons are the most basic method of increasing one's offensive power. Just having a weapon and attacking an enemy is often enough to make you a substantial threat, regardless of your expertise or abilities.Weapons fall into Weapon Groups for the purpose of identifying what Special Attacks, Abilities, and Techniques they're compatible with. The categories describe how they are used to attack, rather than how they look. If a weapon has more than one main category, then that means its category changes based on the way it is used, such as throwing a dagger instead of swinging it.There are ten main categories:And 4 subtypes:
Exotic Weapons do not neatly fit into these categories, and will list how they differ.Weapons come with damage values, attack speed values, and damage types as their core stats, in addition to the categories listed above.
All standard weapons deal a physical Damage type. If a weapon has more than one damage type, you can decide which to use before you make a given attack with it.
Damage values and Attack Speed correlate such that the damage tends to be very similar without any additional abilities or STR. The typical offense-oriented damage values and AS are as follows:
Weapons with ranged capabilities (thrown or otherwise) will also have a listed range. Ranges come in an X/Y format, with the X range being the accurate range, and the Y taking a -4 penalty, referred to as the Range.
Some weapons come with Techniques and Special Attacks. These temporarily grant you a technique as long as you wield them. As per the Mana rules, you cannot sacrifice your own Mana to get another use of a Limited Technique unless otherwise stated. Special Attacks specifically are also tied to the weapon - If you use the Special Attack, you cannot pass the weapon off to another creature to use it again, and the weapon has its own Recharge timer.
Many weapons come with Weapon Qualities. These describe what a weapon does beyond its classification, Damage, and AS.Unless otherwise stated, Weapons weights default to the following:

item.title: Weapon Group
item.description:
A Weapon Group is a categorization of Weapons that describes the way it is used in combat, and is used to identify what Special Attacks, Abilities, and Techniques they're compatible with. The categories describe how they are used to attack, rather than how they look. If a weapon has more than one main category, then that means its category changes based on the way it is used, such as throwing a dagger instead of swinging it.
There are 10 main groups: Axe, Blade, Bludgeon, Bow, Close, Dagger, Polearm, Thrown/Caster, Thrust, and Trigger,
and 4 sub-groups: Ammunition, Natural, Shield, and Staff.

item.title: Simple Attack
item.description: Simple attacks are only rolling attack and damage, typically with no special effects tied to them. Special attacks allow for more versatility in play style. Unique weapons, class abilities, techniques and feats can grant these special attacks. Special attacks can usually only be performed once per turn.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Attacking/Simple Attack.md

item.title: Poison
item.description: Poison is a Damage type Tag, representing an toxic or caustic substance that melts away the body as well as objects.

item.title: Nebula
item.description:
Tier 2 Lunar Spell
Action-Attack, Recharge
Force, Light
Evocation
Conjure a cloud of stardust that illuminates in a 20 ft radius beyond its borders. It obscures vision through it beyond 5 feet, granting Partial Concealment. Anything beyond 5 feet grants Total Concealment. At the end of the spell's duration, it erupts, dealing 2 SP+CL Force Damage to all creatures in the area.
Upcast 1 - +1 SP Damage

item.title: Vengeance Other
item.description:
Tier 4 Lunar Spell
Standard Action, Limited
Buff
Evocation
Functions as Vengeance, but on a creature other than yourself. It cannot be cast reactively.
You reflect 75% of the next instance of damage you take as Force Damage back at the attacker.
This spell is particularly easy to identify due to its distinct visual effect of a skull appearing over your head, making the DC to Identify Spell 10 points lower.

item.title: Vengeance
item.description:
Tier 3 Lunar Spell
Immediate Action, Recharge
Buff
Evocation
You may cast this spell in response to an Attack, AoE, or Targeted effect being declared on you, but before its result is known. You may also cast it at any point on your turn. Remind your DM to announce attacks before making them to make casting this spell less awkward.
You reflect 75% of the next instance of damage you take as Force Damage back at the attacker.
This spell is particularly easy to identify due to its distinct visual effect of a skull appearing over your head, making the DC to Identify Spell 10 points lower.

item.title: Enchant Sapphire
item.description:
Tier 1 Lunar Spell
1 Hour Cast Time, At-Will M - Sapphire Jewelry or a Sapphire, worth at least 500g
Divination, TransmutationYou cast a spell on a Sapphire jewel or jewelry, turning it into a consumable magic item. The effects vary based on where the item goes on the body. Jewelry pieces take up Equipment Slots.

item.title: Magic Claw
item.description:
Tier 1 Academy Spell
Action-Attack, At-Will
Evocation
Target takes SP Force Damage on a failed save.
Upcast 1 - Add Spell Power to damage.

item.title: Mana
item.description:
Mana is the resource that enables all sorts of things. For the purposes of this explanation, mana is primary used to fuel Techniques. It also fuels mana class abilities and is a crafting component. Mana itself has value.Mana Basics In order to use a technique, you must spend mana equal to the tier of technique. Cantrips have an effective tier of 0 and do not cost mana. While not in immediate danger (such as combat or a chase), you regenerate 1 mana per turn, or 10 mana per minute.Upcast
By spending more mana, you can increase the effectiveness of abilities with the Upcast tag. The degree to which varies by ability. Just because you have enough mana in your pool does not mean you can upcast an ability.
In order to upcast, you must meet a certain level requirement (see mana basics above) in addition to increasing the mana cost. For example imagination has options up to upcast 5, effectively making that option a level 5 technique, requiring you to be level 9 to use it.Mana Reserves Mana reserves function exactly like your base mana, except they disappear after used, and only regenerate after you rest. Mana reserves are gained through having positive intelligence, are sometimes given to mage classes and through magic items, often with particular restrictions on their use.Mana Burn
Abilities with the tag Mana Burn either reduce your max mana, or have an optional more powerful use case that reduces your max mana. Reduces by 1 unless stated otherwise. Usually goes away on rest. If an ability does not mention a mana cost, then it still reduces current and max mana by 1 if it has the mana burn tag.For clarity: Mana burn does not happen in addition to any mana cost. Mana burn typically serves to weaken a character over an adventuring day, rather than providing an immediate drawback.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/Mana.md

item.title: Graze
item.description: Graze is an attack that is not a complete miss. When you roll below the targets AC, but not by more than 5, then the attack does half damage. A graze does not apply any on-hit effects, like bleed.

item.title: Shove
item.description: Push the target 10ft away from you.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Attacking/Combat Maneuvers/Shove.md

item.title: Drag
item.description: Requires a free hand or prehensile appendage. Target creature stays adjacent to you for the remainder of your turn, up to 30 ft. This is reduced to 10 feet if they are larger than you and you do not possess exceptional strength with which to carry them. If the creature is not adjacent to you when you successfully drag, they are automatically pulled adjacent to you. You can choose any space within your natural reach to place the creature in at the end of your drag (both of these count against the distance you can drag).Special: You must use at least one prehensile limb to initiate a drag on a creature, unless your weapon has the CM Drag property.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Attacking/Combat Maneuvers/Drag.md

item.title: Shimmering Ray
item.description:
Tier 2 Prismancy Spell
Action-Attack, Recharge
Fire, Light
Evocation
Make a Ranged Attack that deals 2 SP Fire Damage, and the target begins Glowing.
If the target is Glowing, this instead consumes the Glowing status, ending any Concentration effects, any Grapple they are holding, and inflicting Blurred Vision for one round.
Upcast 1 - +1 SP Damage

item.title: Foe Throw
item.description:
Tier 1 Savagery Technique
Action-Attack AS 2, Recharge
Throw a creature you are grabbing at another. Both take 2d10 damage and fall Prone. The target gets a Reflex save to negate the effect. The thrown creature ends in an adjacent empty space closest to you. You do not need to target a second creature with this ability; you can choose to target any space. This counts as a weapon with the Thrown property.
Upcast 1 - Damage increases by d10.

item.title: +Combat Maneuver
item.description:
Combat Maneuvers are attacks that target Poise. When making a Combat Maneuver, you must decide which specific form it takes, such as a Knockdown, Dirty Trick, or Shove. A successful Combat Maneuver will inflict a condition based on the form you chose. See:
Dirty Trick
Disarm
Drag
Feint
Knock Down
Grapple
Shove
Steal
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Attacking/Combat Maneuvers/+Combat Maneuver.md

item.title: Seismic Stomp
item.description:
Tier 2 Savagery Technique
Action-Attack, Recharge
Attempt a Knock Down at +4, rolling once against all creatures within 10 Ft. If successful, the creatures also take 2d6 Crush Damage.
Upcast 1 - +2 bonus, additional d6 damage.

item.title: Polearm
item.description:
Polearms are a group of Weapons that are 2-handed. These are long skirmish weapons for battlefield versatility. They combine the spacing of spears with the swings of axes. Often used to hook enemies in addition to being general weapons.
The following are the Basic Weapons in the Polearm group.
item.guid: Equipment/Weapon Rules/Weapon Types and Basic Weapons/Polearm.md

item.title: Knocked Down
item.description: Creature takes a -30 penalty to speed and attacks get a +2 bonus to attack against them until the start of the inflicting creature or effect's next turn, at which point the condition ends, unless the creature is Held Down.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Knocked Down.md

item.title: Bully
item.description: Deal poise damage to a creature that cannot reduce them below 1 poise, with the intention to combo. Bully uses the highest bonus you have to a specific combat maneuver. So if you have a +4 bonus to attack to shove and +8 to grapple, bully is rolled at +8.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Attacking/Combat Maneuvers/Bully.md

item.title: Dirty Trick
item.description: Apply clumsy 1, sickened 1 or blurred vision to a creature. They must spend a standard action to get rid of the condition.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Attacking/Combat Maneuvers/Dirty Trick.md

item.title: Get Down!
item.description: Throw yourself into the way of an attack made against a helpless creature. This could mean a minion, someone who is asleep or defeated. You can choose to become the target of all danger aimed at them, including AoE, spells and attacks. Such attacks automatically hit you and you get no saving throws against spells.You naturally need to be aware of an attack to protect against it. If a creature manages to give you the slip with stealth, then you can't protect.If the attack was originally a crit, it crits you instead automatically. AoE effects harm you twice.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Common Actions/Swift and Immediate Actions/Get Down!.md

item.title: Jump
item.description:
Jump in a straight line. This can only be used in combination with other forms of movement such as walking or charging.Jump is also a statistic distance. By default, your Jump is 5. This is a measure of distance, specifically for horizontal jumps, while vertical jumps are half. This does not give you additional movement, and thus it is limited by your Speed, unless your Jump is higher than your Speed (in which case it functions as your total movement limit when jumping). It can be used to avoid Difficult Terrain, but not if you're already in the Difficult Terrain.
You can only jump once with this action. If you Dash, you can jump twice. These jumps do not need to be consecutive.
Jump distance increases by 5 ft per point of STR (and DEX with Acrobatics).
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Common Actions/Swift and Immediate Actions/Jump.md

item.title: Dash
item.description: Double your speed this round. Has no effect if your speed is zero.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Common Actions/Standard Actions/Dash.md

item.title: Charge
item.description: Move at twice your speed in a straight line, halting when your foe is adjacent, or at least within reach. Make your attack(s) against a creature. Creatures get a +2 bonus to attack against you until the start of your next turn. If your charge gets interrupted for whatever reason, you must make your attack(s) from your halted position. You cannot charge a creature that is adjacent to you.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Common Actions/Standard Actions/Charge.md

item.title: Delay
item.description: You can decide to wait to act in initiative, acting whenever you like at the end of another creature's turn, permanently changing your position in initiative.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Common Actions/Free Actions/Delay.md

item.title: Instant Action
item.description: Instant Action: A Free Action that can occur off-turn.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Action System/Instant Action.md

item.title: Full-Round Action
item.description: Full-Round Action: This action requires the use of your standard action and all of your movement. You may still move if you have an ability that allows extra movement as a different action.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Action System/Full-Round Action.md

item.title: Action System
item.description:
This game is played turn-based, with turn order determined at the start of the battle with an Initiative roll. The actions you can take on your turn are as follows. Standard Action: This action occupies most of your turn, and you can perform one per turn.
Swift Action: This action can be executed during any other action, with a limit of one per turn.
Free Action: These actions are effortless or part of other actions, allowing you to perform as many as you wish per turn - within reason.
Full-Round Action: This action requires the use of your standard action and all of your Movement. You may still move if you have an ability that allows extra movement as a different action.
Movement: You can move up to your Speed on your turn. Some abilities or effects may require spending a certain amount of your movement for the turn. You may have other forms of movement that manifest in terms of different Speeds - you may use multiple forms of movement on the same turn, but only up to the maximum amount for the given speed. Any slower speeds used overlap - That is, if you have a Fly 40 and a ground speed of 30, you may walk 30 feet and then fly another 10. When it's not your turn, you can take the following actions:
Immediate Action: A Swift Action that can occur off-turn. Limited to one per round, shared with Swift Action — you cannot use both in the same round.
Instant Action: A Free Action that can occur off-turn. Referred to as "Instantly" in abilities.
Attack of Opportunity: A response triggered by certain actions of others. Limited to one per round. When a creature "Provokes," they are engaging in an action that allows others to AoO them.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Action System/Action System.md

item.title: Hover
item.description:
Hover is a lesser version of flight, where the creature is limited to hovering a few feet above the ground. Hover Speeds allow Movement above solid and liquid surfaces while ignoring Difficult Terrain.
A creature that is Grounded cannot hover.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Action System/Movement/Hover.md

item.title: Fly
item.description:
Fly Speeds allow Movement in any direction. They may remain in the air as long as they have a Fly
A creature that is Entangled or Grounded cannot continue flight.
A creature that takes damage from an Attack or AoE effect while flying receives Clumsy 1 until they land, up to 4 stacks.
Starting to fly is a Swift Action that Provokes as if leaving a Threatened space.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Action System/Movement/Fly.md

item.title: Luck Check
item.description: When playing table top, a lot of things aren't well defined until they get into render distance, which basically means when players ask about it. When a situation pops up where your player asks for a specific circumstance like "Is the door to the armory locked?" "is there a hat store in town?" or "are there any footholds on the side of this cliff?" and you don't immediately have a response, the character in question rolls a luck check. If it's a general party question, or if you bring your lucky friend with you during your shopping trip, they could reasonably roll it instead.Again, if you already had an answer in mind, don't roll this. This is something that you should use in moderation. The moment you let your players start rolling this again and again is when all cohesion in your world evaporates
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Ability Scores/Luck Check.md

item.title: Carry Weight
item.description: A creature's Carry Weight represents what it is capable of lifting and moving around with without much effort.The default value is 100.A creature can lift and drag twice as much as their carry weight, but is staggered while doing so.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Ability Scores/Carry Weight.md

item.title: XP
item.description:
Crusty content Experience is a meta-currency gained through prioritizing primary campaign events that allows players to influence the story/chronological order of things in order to accomplish personal goals quickly and get back into the action faster. As a baseline, 10 XP is the equivalent of one in-game day of events.
Experience is rewarded for spending time working towards campaign goals in an active manner. This mainly means exploring dungeons, splitting heads, and overthrowing governments - anything that is both related to the main campaign objectives, and is not part of downtime events (such as recovering from an Affliction or Crafting). XP is rewarded based on the time required to complete the mission, with additional bonuses for overcoming particular challenges. The purpose of XP is to reward taking action. While downtime is an important part of roleplay, it's easy to justify staying in town making safe money or doing side quests to save up for a shiny new weapon or achieve personal goals if there isn't an obvious time constraint on important story events. It's easy to hold off on an important event and try to squeeze a few more days of crafting into your schedule. Instead, XP serves to reward taking action immediately, without penalizing downtime events like crafting.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/XP.md

item.title: Technique Point
item.description: A technique point gives you access to the next tier of a technique tree equal to the number of points you have invested in it, from 1 to 6. Most classes get technique points on odd levels, and all player characters get technique points on even levels.You are capped at how many technique points you can put into a tree by your Lv. Level 1 characters can only have access to tier 1 tech, level 3 get tier 2 and so on.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/Technique Point.md

item.title: Memory
item.description: Memory determines how many Techniques you can have at your disposal at once. At the start of each day, you can prepare a number of techniques equal to your memory, chosen from any technique trees you have technique points invested into.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/Memory.md

item.title: Mana Burn
item.description: Mana Burn is the loss of a daily Mana such that it cannot be recovered until you take a Long Rest, and needing to re-prepare the ability to another slot to use it again. This is usually voluntary, but can also be the result of an offensive effect.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Mana Burn.md

item.title: Crust
item.description: Crusty Content is content that I believe is still too early in development to be worth your time. It will often be incomplete and imbalanced.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/Crust.md

item.title: Roll
item.description: The default die roll for resolving things. This is used to determine the variance expected.In Nick Nacks, this is a 20 sided dice for most rolls. Other dice are typically only used in damage rolls and other niche cases.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/Roll.md

item.title: PC
item.description: Player Character (PC): A character controlled by a player, and not the GM. Players are the main characters of a story, and thus gain priority in some aspects.Sometimes, a DM will play a special character alongside the players that is treated like a PC. This is normal, but the players can veto such a character's PC status if they feel it is inappropriate.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/PC.md

item.title: Initiative
item.description:
Nick Nacks is a turn-based game, and initiative decides who goes firstOne of the players rolls a d10. On a 6 or higher, the players go first, or a 5 or lower, the enemies go first. On the first round of combat, whichever party went first decides which creature acts first. Then you swap to the other party and they decide who goes. You repeat this process until either every creature has acted, or one side has several creatures that haven't acted. All remaining creatures act on the same turn and then you start back from the top, using the same order as round 1.When initiative is rolled, all Buff effects disappear automatically (unless its duration is longer than 1 minute). This is to discourage spamming buffing spells and then waiting to recover mana.
Surprise In DnD and its derivatives, if you get the jump on your opponent, the sneaky party gets an entire turn to themselves. This is not the case in Nick Nacks. The conventional "surprise round" is now a normal round in combat.All characters that are surprised lose are DD during the first round, and the surprising party always goes first in initiative. Surprise can be a bit finicky sometimes, making you question if only some characters should be surprised. If that's what your gut tells you, that's how it is.For example, your party's rogue who was hiding in an alley ambushes a group of guardsmen that are harassing the rest of the party. The guard captain notices but his men do not. Captain is not DD, the rest are.What happens when our party starts fighting in the middle of talking? In the event where there are two parties that don't immediately fight, when initiative starts is usually determined by whenever someone takes an aggressive action, such as casting a spell or drawing an arrow. In these cases, where both parties are aware of each other, initiative gets rolled immediately before any actions happen.Certain types of underhanded tactics can get around this, such as using sleight of hand to draw concealed weapons or deception for a sucker punch. See surprise for more details.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/Initiative.md

item.title: DD
item.description: "Denied Dodge" Creature is unable to respond effectively to attacks due to Stealth, Feinting, or some other status or Circumstance. Attacks made against a Surprised creature get a +4 bonus.This status effect is also a Circumstance that can be determined on a per-creature or per-attack basis, but can also be a condition that applies to all incoming attacks.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/DD.md

item.title: Blindspot
item.description:
Tier 1 Deceit Technique
Action-Attack, Recharge
Elusive
Move to the opposite side of a creature and make a melee Attack against it. It is DD against this attack.

item.title: Pickpocket
item.description: As a Standard Action, use Trained Hands on a distracted or DD creature to pilfer an object off of their person. This is opposed to the Perception of the target and any nearby creatures that can witness you. Failure indicates that the target noticed an unwanted intrusion on their person, and the theft fails. Items that are closely bound to the target cause a -5 penalty to Pickpocket. Items that are worn or held in the hands cannot be pickpocketed.

item.title: Conceal Item
item.description:
Use Hands to conceal an item on your person. Should someone search you or otherwise have access to you to find such an item (such as if your clothes was lifted), you must roll Hands against their Perception to prevent them from discovering the item. Concealed items cannot be procured as a Free Action or Instant Action.
You can use Trained Hands as a Swift Action to draw a concealed weapon. If you win the opposed check, the target is DD against your next attack. You can use this as an alternative to Stealth to Surprise an enemy when you are otherwise in a neutral position, and the opposing party is aware of you.

item.title: Sucker Punch
item.description: If you are in some kind of standoff where you aren't quite fighting your enemy yet, you can use Trained Deception or Trained Hands as a replacement for Stealth to Surprise your enemy with a melee Attack. The enemy must be aware of you in order to Sucker Punch, otherwise it is Stealth, and you must already be adjacent to use Hands for it. If you don't use an Unarmed Strike, then you have disadvantage on this check, unless you use Hands.Certain situations where you are not able to get close to your aggressors, such as having bows pointed at you from a garrison above you, make Sucker Punching impossible.

item.title: Blind Fight
item.description:
Combat Feat
You are not DD while Blinded. You ignore Concealment AC bonuses.

item.title: Stunned
item.description: A more extreme form of being Dazed. Creature cannot take any actions or movement. Creature is DD.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Stunned.md

item.title: Blinded
item.description: Sighted creature takes a -10 penalty to Perception and treats all creatures as though they had Total Concealment. Creatures' vision range decreases to 10 ft. Creature is also DD.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Blinded.md

item.title: Concealment
item.description:
Concealment is a Circumstance that is gained when a creature's position is being obscured from another's Senses.
Usually, this means an effect like fog or darkness is partially or totally hiding a creature from another, resulting in Partial Concealment or Total Concealment, but this may take other forms against creatures that have other senses.
Concealment is a condition that's relative to the senses of other creatures. If you have Dark Vision and your opponent doesn't in a situation with Darkness, you have concealment against them, but they don't have concealment to you.
Attacking from concealment, even Total Concealment, does not Surprise by default. You still need to use Stealth as normal.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/Cover/Concealment.md

item.title: GM
item.description: Game Master (GM): The person running the game. This person is the arbiter of the rules, tasked with creating the world, playing all NPCs, and ensuring a fun and fair experience for the players.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/GM.md

item.title: Weather and Terrain vs Spells
item.description:
Certain high level spells manipulate the weather or terrain in drastic ways. If multiple casters attempt to cast different spells that affect the same weather, the higher CL always wins.
In the event where the caster tries to interfere with weather that is supernaturally powerful (created by natural magic, associated with cursed terrain, etc.), the GM should assign the effect an effective CL.All weather-inducing spells do not function underground.With smaller-scale terrain changes or unforeseen interactions between spells and an environment, an opposed CL check is more appropriate.
item.guid: Techniques/Spellcasting Rules/Weather and Terrain vs Spells.md

item.title: Skill
item.description:
Skill Rolls are how players interact with the world without hitting it with their sword. Even if certain actions have a skill associated with them, you don't necessarily need to roll a skill check (no need to roll Deception if they already believe you, no need to roll Athletics in still water, etc.) When one is required, it is prompted by the GM.
If the DC to a task is more than 30 points higher than the bonus on the roll, then the DM should deem it impossible in cases where "fishing" for a success with no repercussions is the intent. The special roll allows rolling any number, so if a task is well out of a character's reach such that the DC difference is that high, it may be better to not allow the roll to preserve the narrative.
This roll can be very swingy, creating dramatically unexpected results. As such, using a skill roll as a barrier for entry can create all or nothing scenarios. There's nothing wrong with saying "the lock is too complex for you to pick," but you can't be upset when immediately after the martials of the party start smashing into the door. There should be lesser versions of success. If you barely fail the DC to scale a wall, it lowers your speed instead of falling. If you barely fail a Stealth check while trailing someone, they can tell someone is in the bushes, but not who.Many things should not be represented by a skill or ability roll. For example, do not roll to see if someone can lift a portcullis - This is already represented by their Carrying Capacity. You should also carefully consider what a roll represents, and whether rerolls are appropriate. When rolls are made, don't be surprised when the party's expert sometimes gets outdone by the party's pet chicken. A skill check should be summarized with a "you can or you can't" when rolling may cause inconsistencies.
Skill bonuses are increased by one relevant Ability Score modifier. You add 2x the bonus to your skill check if you are Proficient.
Proficiency in a skill grants you a 2+LV bonus to the skill. Certain aspects of a skill might only be available to characters that are proficient in the skill.
Standard skill DCs are what should be used in the absence of a set or opposed DC. Remember that every 10 point difference makes the task twice as hard. They are as follows…Some skills are opposed to other skills, while other skills will include examples comparable this chart.

item.title: Detect Dishonesty
item.description:
Whenever a creature makes a statement, you can roll Insight (opposed by Deception) to see if what they say aligns with what they think. If you roll lower, or if they aren't being dishonest, you don't detect dishonesty. If you succeed, you determine that something is fishy - or if a statement lacks nuance (such as a yes or no response), you can determine the correct answer. Prying further about the deception may cause the creature to reveal the truth or become hostile depending on context.
This can be combined with Deception against their Insight to hide whether or not they know you know they're being dishonest. When this is done, it may be more entertaining to have the GM roll in secret, and distribute results in secret, in order to preserve tension.You can only roll Insight on a particular assertion or topic once.

item.title: Lie
item.description:
Use Deception against a target's Insight to speak falsehoods, or to soften the truth. See Detect Dishonesty. It may be more entertaining if the GM rolls this in secret to preserve tension.
Common modifiers to increase the DC include: The target has firsthand experience with the events Claims that are fantastical or impossible, such as equating angels with demons or asserting a green sky The target is knowledgeable of the subject matter Common modifiers to make the task less difficult can include: The target is inattentive, such as from being tired or drunk The target trusts you

item.title: Stat Feat
item.description:
A Stat Feat grants numerical bonuses, such as to Skills or ACC, usually unconditionally, and not much else.
These are for rounding out weaknesses and giving an indecisive PC or GM an easy pick-me.

item.title: NPC
item.description:
Non-Player Character (NPC): Any character that is played by the GM.
These characters usually get placed after PCs to favor the players.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/NPC.md

item.title: Total Concealment
item.description:
Total Concealment is a Circumstance that decreases attacker's ACC by 4.
When you have Total Concealment, a creature cannot see you at all. Either they are Blinded, you are completely hidden in an environmental or magical effect, or you are Invisible.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/Cover/Total Concealment.md

item.title: Partial Concealment
item.description: Partial Concealment is a Circumstance that decreases attacker's ACC by 2. When you have Partial Concealment, a creature can still see you, but in a limited capacity. Either they can only see your shadow, they're trying to avert your gaze, or there are poor environmental conditions/magic at play.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/Cover/Partial Concealment.md

item.title: Improved Cover
item.description:
Improved Cover is an environmental Circumstance that increases your AC and Reflex by 4.
Improved Cover is received against Ranged Attacks and AoEs that target you while there are obstacles between you and the source of the attack that obscure almost all of your space, usually intentionally designed to allow attacks only in one direction, and that cannot be pierced by the attack.
Examples include arrow slits and murder holes., as well as ranged weapon attacks against Submerged targets.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/Cover/Improved Cover.md

item.title: Cover
item.description:
Cover is an environmental Circumstance that increases your AC and Reflex by 2.
Standard Cover is received against Ranged Attacks and AoEs that target you while there are obstacles between you and the source of the attack that obscure a large portion of your space, and that cannot be pierced by the attack.
Better forms of cover result in Improved Cover and Total Cover.Examples include peeking around a pillar, over a trench, or behind a low wall.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/Cover/Cover.md

item.title: AC
item.description:
Armor Class (AC) is the measure of how difficult it is to hit you. Targets must meet or exceed your AC with an Attack to Damage you.
By default, your starting AC is 10, and you add your LV and Armor. DEX also gets added, but see Armor for how dex interacts with armor. It is also adjusted based on Circumstance.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/AC.md

item.title: Force
item.description: Magic is a Damage type Tag, which represents damage that is supernatural in origin, forces rending and unmaking through means that cannot be described by physical processes.

item.title: Knock Down
item.description: Inflict Knocked Down.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Attacking/Combat Maneuvers/Knock Down.md

item.title: Use Potion
item.description: Retrieve and drink a potion.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Common Actions/Swift and Immediate Actions/Use Potion.md

item.description:
Tier 1 Academy Spell
Standard Action, Recharge
Sigil
Divination
You inscribe a magic rune on the surface of an object. Whenever a creature of at least tiny or larger Size enters this area, the sigil triggers, creating one of two effects you decide upon casting. In either case, you are mentally alerted and awakened if Asleep.Silent Alarm - Only you are mentally alerted. Loud Alarm - A loud sound plays. Creatures within 300 ft can hear it in ideal conditions.This spell only functions while you are inside its radius.

item.title: Necromancy
item.description: Necromancy focuses on the creation of Undead creatures

item.title: Sabre of Light
item.description:
Tier 4 Prismancy Spell
Swift Action, Recharge
Fire, Light, Martial
Evocation
Imbue a melee slashing weapon in hand with searing light and make an attack with it, adding +CL ACC and SP+CL Fire Damage.

item.title: Ricochet Reflection
item.description:
Tier 2 Prismancy Spell
Swift Action, Recharge
Light, Concentration
Evocation
You create a zone that twists light and projectiles that appears as a giant mirror. Any creature that can see the mirror can use it to curve their Line of Effect, and to determine Cover, unlike a regular mirror. This also functions for projectiles and line attacks, as the mirror curves their trajectories towards whatever you see in the mirror.

item.title: Prismatic Barrier
item.description:
Tier 2 Prismancy Spell
Action-Attack, Recharge
Light, Healing
Abnegation
Grant allies and yourself 2 SP Temp HP for one round. Enemies must make Reflex saves or begin Glowing for one round.
Upcast 1 - +1 SP Temp HP

Upcast 1 -

item.title: Astral Alignment
item.description:
Tier 3 Lunar Spell
Standard Action, Limited
Divination
You can foresee the alignment of the heavens, but you do not know when it will occur. Add +4 to your next Luck Check.

item.title: Spell
item.description:
Spellcasting is a general title that applies to a specific type of magical effect, with specific rules. Spells do not encompass all magic, but it is the most common type. Most Spells are Techniques.
All spells have some kind of visual effect associated with their casting before the effect occurs. Magic circles shining fingers and eyes, words manifesting into physical objects and circling the caster are all means to easily identify when a creature is casting a spell. The only exception to this is spells with the Subtle tag.
This is also the case for Innate Casting.
Spellcasting takes into account your Caster Level and Spell Power, and requires using Somatic, Material, and Verbal Components (Innate Casting does not require components).

item.description:
Tier 1 Vitalism Spell
Standard Action, At-Will
Evocation

item.title: Skewer
item.description:
Weapon Innate Technique
Action-Attack, Recharge
Compatible with these Weapon Groups:
Blade
Bow
Thrown
Thrust
Trigger
Weapon must deal Pierce Damage.Make an attack against a target. If you hit, target an additional adjacent target that is on the opposite side of them. Continue making attacks until you miss or deal no damage, or there are no more adjacent targets in a line. If using a melee weapon, the additional targets do not need to be in reach.

item.title: Marksmanship
item.description: Technique Tree.Marksmanship focuses on the use of ranged weaponry, strategy, and nimble footwork to dominate the battlefield.

item.title: Savagery
item.description: Technique Tree.Savagery embodies the raw, untamed essence of primal fury, and visceral instincts. Those who follow this path tap into a wellspring of unrelenting strength and ferocity, transforming their bodies into instruments of destruction. With each blow, they become forceful avatars of chaos, rending flesh and shattering earth beneath their feet. Their rage fuels an indomitable resilience, allowing them to shrug off pain as they rampage through the battlefield, leaving piles of corpses and the ruins of civilization in their wake as they advance with their bodies painted in the blood of their foes.

item.title: Invigorate
item.description:
Tier 1 Vitalism Spell
Action-Attack, Recharge
ConjurationThe target gains a new save against one ongoing effect that is not permanent.
They also stand up from Knocked Down, and their weapons gain +1 AS on their next turn.

item.title: Bless
item.description:
Tier 1 Vitalism Spell
Action-Attack, Recharge
Holy, Concentration, Buff
Conjuration
The target gets +2 ACC, and its physical Attacks gain Holy Damage.

item.title: Caloric Healing
item.description:
Tier 1 Vitalism Spell
Standard Action, Recharge
Healing, Caloric
Conjuration
Burn a Food item in hand to heal the target for half of what the Food normally heals. This doesn't grant any other bonuses that come with the sacrificed item.

item.title: Heal
item.description:
Tier 1 Vitalism Spell
Standard Action, Limited
Healing
Conjuration
Heal yourself and allies for 2 SP+CL, and end Bleed effects.
Undead must save or take this as Holy Damage.
Upcast 1 - +SP Healing.

item.title: Spare Life
item.description:
Tier 1 Vitalism Spell
Standard Action, At-Will
Healing
ConjurationYou bind the target's soul, composition, and magic in place, which brings it back to life for 2 Rounds. It will die again in 2 Rounds, unless it is healed to 0 HP or higher, and the effects that killed it are removed (such as stitching its head back on, or removing a death curse). You can cast this spell again if the target dies again, as long as you cast it within the time limit.

item.title: Short Rest
item.description: Taking a Short Rest requires being in a place with no immediate threats or hazards for at least 15 minutes, where you can eat and stretch and wipe your brow to benefit from Natural Healing. During a Short Rest, you can Prepare Techniques.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Hitpoints/Short Rest.md

item.title: Vitalism
item.description: Vitalism spells are a supporting caster's best toolkit. They are tailored towards protecting the sanctity of life, and reaching and increasing the strength of allies. These spells are typically Holy-aligned, and any offensive abilities are typically tailored towards disrupting Fiends and Undead.

item.title: Healer
item.description: Description1 - TechniquesYou gain full progression in Scoundrel and Warfare.1 - Ability1 - Passive

item.title: Bestial
item.description:
Bestial Techniques are collections of abilities that are intended to be used with Natural Weapons. Most are restricted to certain types of attacks, such as claws or tail sweeps.
Beasts and Natural Weapon-wielding creatures from the Bestiary will often have access to these as Innate Techniques.

item.title: Energy Transfer
item.description:
Tier 4 Lunar Spell
Standard Action, Limited
Conjuration
You must have your Recharge action available to use this Spell. You put your Recharge on cooldown to grant another creature the benefits of Recharge.

item.title: Magic Imbue
item.description:
Tier 5 Lunar Spell
Standard Action, Limited
ConjurationYou instantly restore a Limited ability of any kind to the target creature or item.You can only cast this on a given creature or item once per day.

item.title: Unseen Blade
item.description:
Tier 2 Lunar Spell
Swift Action, At-Will
Subtle
Illusion
When making any Attack while the target is in the presence of moonlight, you can turn your weapon or projectile partially invisible to Feint the target right before the attack is made.

item.title: Unseen Form
item.description:
Tier 2 Lunar Spell
Swift Action, Recharge
Subtle, Buff
Illusion
While in the presence of moonlight, you become partially invisible, granting you Total Concealment from creatures beyond 30 feet, and Partial Concealment from any creatures closer.
Taking any actions besides simple interactions or movement reduces the effect to Partial Concealment.

item.title: HP
item.description:
Hitpoints (HP) are a representation of how much offense you can weather. If you run out of HP, you are Defeated. Your total HP is determined primarily by Class, but can also be augmented by abilities, Feats, and even Race.
When you take Damage, you reduce your current HP out of your normal maximum HP. Your current HP value can be negative.Every character with a class starts with 30 HP, with an additional bonus from their class every level (Usually around +10).

item.title: Star Sight
item.description:
Tier 1 Lunar Spell
Standard Action, At-Will
DivinationYou gain a completely unobstructed view of the sky as though it was a clear night. You ignore obtrusive environmental conditions, being indoors and underground, light pollution, and anything similar.
You get a +2 bonus to Navigate.

item.title: Provider's Station
item.description:
Tier 1 Lunar Spell
10 Minute Cast Time, Limited
ConjurationYou must have access to the night sky to cast this spell.When the spell is complete, you create an object or small facility that meets the bare minimum requirements for a particular task, trade, or skill, such as a furnace for heating pottery or a lockpick. This item will break if used for anything other than its intended purpose, and disappears after the spell's duration or if exposed to sunlight.You must create facilities that can fit within a 10ft cube. This spell does not provide fuel to run facilities. It may create objects with multiple parts, such as a series of vials and tubes for use in alchemy, but these cannot be separated from the facility without disappearing.

item.title: Natural Geomancy
item.description:
Tier 1 Lunar Spell
10 Minute Cast Time, At-Will
DivinationFor the duration of this spell, you get a mental ping whenever anything happens to the targeted plant or plot of terrain. You are informed what kind of interaction happened, such as whether it was trampled, touched, clipped, watered, etc. no matter how insignificant the interaction. You're also aware of the environmental conditions they are experiencing, such as approximate temperature, humidity, and even noise level.
For plants, you gain a +2 bonus to Nature checks to determine their health and needs, and can identify such mentally and remotely.This spell does not grant visual stimuli.

item.title: Astrology
item.description:
Tier 1 Lunar Spell
10 Minute Cast Time, At-Will
M - Scroll or Parchment
Divination
When the spell is complete, you convert a scroll or parchment into a Horoscope. The target can read the Horoscope to gain insight into some of the strengths and failings they may have within the next 24 hours. As long as they have the horoscope on their person, they may add 2 to their Roll on a skill check. This cannot be used with Take 10 or Take 30. After they use this benefit, the horoscope disappears.A creature that cannot read cannot benefit from their Horoscope. A creature may only benefit from Astrology once per day.

item.title: Lunar
item.description: Surrounding the magic of the moon are many Lunar Realms, ruled over by a single Lunar Kingdom. The magic of the realms themselves bestowed the royalty of the ruling class, with the Queen and King at the top being given unique wisdom and strength with which to lead their people.The secrets to their magic were closely guarded by the royal family until the last King was murdered in a foreign adversary's coup attempt, and the princess at the time mysteriously disappeared for months. When she returned to take the throne back, she made the secrets of the Moon Queen's Wisdom public knowledge, but the secrets to the Moon King's Strength was forever lost when the Moon Princess died without providing the Lunar Realms a new heir.These spells are based upon the Moon Queen's Wisdom. They focus on abilities passed down from the stars themselves that grant foresight, prosperity, retribution, and access to the ebb and flow of magic from heavenly bodies. Many offensive Lunar spells have delayed or indirect effects.Some Lunar spells require access to the night sky.

item.title: Marine
item.description: Marine Sorceries are sorceries focusing on ocean travel and water-based magics. It is a generalist spell list with diverse spells of somewhat lesser impact than equivalent groups.

item.title: Bandit
item.description:
Rogue Archetype. A professional thief, a blur of shadows around the battlefield taking everything their opponents have and stepping back before they realize what happened. Your very shadow steps out to reach into people's pockets when they aren't looking.1 - Pickpocket
Crits drop coins around the target. When collected, roll Critical Damage to see how many you get; if you collect them, it's worth quadruple. You can collect the coins as a free action, but other creatures must spend an action to collect or otherwise move the money. Before it's looted or moved, the coins are Blood Money. This ability represents taking something away from your opponent with each hit. If you use it while sparring or against allies to "farm" money, they may need that money back to replace the golden tooth they lost, jewelry you pilfered, the kidney you stole etc.
DM discretion.1 - Cunning Action: Steal
You can use Cunning Action to Steal. You can use Steal to produce Blood Money once per creature. Your Cunning Actions have +10 reach.1 - Coin Explosion (Recharge)
Action-Attack. Explode ALL of your Blood Money, dealing your Critical Damage for every pile exploded in their tiles and adjacent tiles. The damage stacks, including with overlap (Reflex halves). You are immune to this damage.Even though each explosion is a separate instance of damage, creatures only roll their save once against all of them.
2 - Band of Thieves Companion Summoning
You can easily find and hire goons to call upon for aid. These are humanoids with half your HP (including when summoned), and +1 DEX and LUK. They are half your level. They have no other abilities or statistics of their own (no techniques, feats, class features, etc).
You may equip them as you please, and Summon them as a Cunning Action as per a Summoning Contract. They take their turn on your turn - the player controls them.
They can use Steal and Critical Hits to create Blood Money for you, using your statistics. They have their own limit for Steal.4 - Grand Larceny
When you use the Steal action, you can Steal from everything in reach.4 - Coin Collection
Gain +20% Wealth.
6 - Assaulter Recharge Teleportation
Action-Attack. Teleport to an enemy that is Surprised, up to 30ft, and Attack.8 - Advanced Dark Sight
Steal no longer ends Dark Sight.
Natural Crits no longer end Dark Sight.
10 - placeholder
